Harry’s hand is steady on his neck, his thumb drawing circles into Regulus’ skin, and he wishes he could stay here. Wishes he could block the world out, the war that’s trying its best to force them apart, while the last few hours have proven nothing more than that there can only ever be victims, one way or another.
“How can you stand it?” he murmurs into Harry’s shoulder, and it’s not really a question. He doesn’t expect an answer, isn’t sure that his brain has caught up with how these are all things that have actually happened to Harry.
Harry hums, the movements of his thumb stilling. “It’s—they’re not like memories to me? Not really anyway. I know it happened, I remember being there and how it felt but it’s not… It doesn’t feel like memories from this life. Like they don’t really belong to me. It’s hard to explain.”
Regulus supposes it would be easier to understand if he had the full picture, and so he draws a deep breath. Wills his heart to return to a steadier rhythm and his eyes to stop burning, and pulls himself from the serenity of Harry’s warmth.
He meets Harry’s eyes, attempting a smile and guessing that it comes out rather weak. “Show me the rest, then. It can’t get much worse.”
Harry doesn’t answer, but his eyes are dark and his grip on Regulus just this side of too tight. He wonders what could possibly be worse than a cave full of Inferi and nightmares and a piece of the Dark Lord’s rotten soul.
As it turns out, it’s possible. Dumbledore dies, and Bellatrix’s cackle and the Death Eaters wreaking havoc on Hogwarts fill him with nothing but scathing contempt.
Nothing but contempt and a sudden, razor-sharp resolution that he’s never going to be part of this. That he’d rather die than stand shoulder to shoulder with people fighting children in a place that is supposed to be a haven. That has been a haven even to someone like him, if only for a few years.
Anything, anything at all has to be better than this.
The scene changes to a wedding, and yet another attack. To Harry and the two of his friends who have been by his side through everything hiding out at Grimmauld Place, making plans to hunt down the remaining Horcruxes on which Dumbledore left sparse information at best.
Sometimes, the memories waver and Harry winces beside him. Amidst everything, Regulus doesn’t question it too much, though he gets the impression that there’s something he’s missing when the wards on Grimmauld Place fall and the three of them end up camping all over England’s countryside.
He forgets all about it, once Harry and Hermione go to Godric’s Hollow and are almost caught by the Dark Lord. When it’s followed by Gryffindor’s sword in a lake it should’ve never appeared in, by being captured and brought to Malfoy Manor, a goblin and a house-elf and breaking into Gringotts.
“You truly have a ridiculous amount of luck,” Regulus laughs when they make it out of Gringotts on the back of a dragon. It’s laughing or turning away, closing his eyes and hoping that he will wake up any second now, left to wonder what the hell had been in his dinner last night.
“It’s a very weird kind of luck,” Harry says, a heaviness underneath the cheer. “It’s lucky at first sight, and then it turns around and utterly fucks me over.”
Regulus would like to argue that successfully breaking into Gringotts doesn’t seem to have a particular downside, but then he witnesses Harry’s vision and the sense of the impending, final battle, and decides that Harry rather has a point.
From the moment the memory shifts to Hogwarts, it’s nothing but chaos. There’s a room full of students, some of whom Regulus recognizes from previous memories, and stories are flying around about the Death Eater’s rule on the school.
Beside him, Harry smiles wistfully, even as the Harry in the memory couldn’t look more uncomfortable with all the attention.
The scene shifts again, leading into another sequence of flashing snippets; the Ravenclaw common room and Harry casting an effortless Cruciatus that, despite everything, Regulus didn’t think him capable of.
The Great Hall once more, though it couldn’t be more different to all the other scenes with students in their nightclothes and the same high-pitched voice echoing through the castle. To a girl from Slytherin calling for Harry to be handed over, and a whole school putting themselves between them, and then Harry’s running through the corridors again.
It ends in the same corridor that Regulus has waited in earlier, and it feels like that must’ve been days ago. What follows is a very different room though, one of which little is left but a charred mess consumed by Fiendfyre and an old diadem bleeding black.
He barely gets time to process any of this before they find themselves in what appears to be a run-down shack with demolished furniture and truly worrying marks on the wall.
Snape is lying on the floor, blood covering his throat and his front. Even more disturbing is the blue substance leaking from him and the way he clings to Harry.
Just as Voldemort’s voice starts ringing again, the memory dissolves.
At Regulus’ questioning glance, Harry shakes his head. “I’d rather relive as little of all this as possible if I don’t absolutely have to,” he says, and it quells the little curiosity that Regulus has left.
What forms next is clearly the headmaster’s office, although it looks completely different from how he remembers it from the other memories.
Harry’s alone this time, staring around the room with dark, grief-laden eyes. He approaches a cupboard and pulls out the Pensive, watching dispassionately as he pours Snape’s memories into it.
Regulus would be lying if he said that he doesn’t want to know what role Snape played in this whole story. The few glimpses of him in the memories never indicated that he had any sympathy for Harry. Regulus vaguely remembers from their—his—own time the friendship between Snape and Lily Evans, but he assumed that it must’ve ended in Harry’s timeline as well.
As it turns out, it did; the first few memories are all about said friendship, showing that there was much more to it than Regulus had ever paid attention to. There’s a bitter irony in how there are certain parallels to how his and Harry’s friendship had developed, even as he would take a guess and claim that Snape was doing none of it against his will.
Then again, it’s not like Regulus didn’t make a choice either, as much as he liked to tell himself that there was no other way.
It still catches him off guard when it’s Snape who overhears the prophecy and reveals it to Voldemort. When he meets with Dumbledore and begs him to save Lily Evans, making no secret out of how very little he cares about her husband or her son.
Regulus never had much to do with him but seeing this, he’s rather sure that it wasn’t little enough. By far.
He also didn’t think it possible for his opinion of Dumbledore to sink any lower, but it does, even more so when the memories start aligning with Harry’s school years. 
Harry’s rigid beside him, his fingers tight around Regulus’ hand. Regulus wonders if it’s the whole history between Snape and his mother—and it’s still not any less weird, to think of a girl only one year older than them as Harry’s mother—or if it’s Dumbledore.
The question is answered not much later, in the very same office. Out of everything they’ve seen, after all the horrors, this is by far, by far the absolute worst of it.
You raised him like a pig for slaughter, Snape says, and Regulus can’t find it within himself to be mad about how very much he agrees.
Can’t find it within himself to tamp down on the absolute hatred boiling underneath his skin at how, when Harry emerges from the Pensive, he’s already wearing an expression of acceptance. Of how he puts on the Invisibility Cloak and walks through the school, stopping to look at his friends one last time, and leaves for the Forbidden Forest.
Leaves and walks towards his death as if it is a foregone conclusion.
Regulus has to look away from the scene in the clearing when Harry pulls the cloak off. Has to look at the Harry beside him, trace the lines of his face with his eyes and assure himself that somehow, miraculously, he’s right here, blessedly breathing and alive. His palm warm, still so very warm against Regulus’, and in that moment—
In that moment between following the lines of Harry’s scar, and the green light illuminating the clearing, Regulus couldn’t care less for how or why Harry is here now. Only that he is and that it doesn’t matter at all what brought him here.
The boy in the clearing crumbles, and so does the memory. It takes Regulus long moments to comprehend that it hasn’t ended; that the white, foggy space around them isn’t the same as lingering between memories, but a memory itself.
His head is starting to ache with how very convoluted all of this is.
Slowly, the space around them changes, and Regulus stares in disbelief as he starts recognizing Kings Cross.
Before he gets a chance to ask, a whimpering noise snags up his attention.
“The Horcrux,” Harry says quietly, and Regulus wonders how he can be so calm. 
Regulus would’ve never been able to stand even half of the things he’s seen tonight. Would’ve tried to claw Dumbledore’s eyes out with his bare hands the moment he appears, still spinning fabulous tales.
Harry doesn’t, though, and only half of what Dumbledore’s saying makes any sense but then the memory changes back to the very same clearing and a weakened Voldemort.
It’s Narcissa, of all people, who declares Harry dead despite the opposite clearly being the case. Through all the ice that has made itself a home in the hollows between Regulus’ bones, there’s a spark of warmth at her one act of defiance.
Voldemort believes her, and things quickly become too fast-paced again to follow; the walk back to the castle, Voldemort’s posturing in the courtyard while none of his spells hold, and a whole barrage of creatures appearing out of nowhere.
Regulus does catch the movement when Harry jumps up; keeps his eyes fixed on him as he storms into the school with everyone else, even if they’re the only ones who can—somehow—see him underneath the Invisibility Cloak.
In fact, Regulus is so focused on him that he almost misses the throng of house-elves joining the battle. Almost misses that the elf at the front is Kreacher, much older and more worn, but with a vigour that Regulus cannot remember ever seeing on him. He wants to ask, wants to stop and hear what Kreacher is about to shout, but Harry jerks next to him and the memory shudders, depositing them in the middle of the deadly silent Great Hall.
“What—” Regulus starts, but Harry shakes his head sharply and Regulus doesn’t dare finish his question.
He bites his lip and tries to steel himself for whatever is about to happen next. There’s no doubt that they’re nearing the end of it, and while he has found out so much more than he ever expected to—so much more than he wanted, maybe—he still feels like he’s missing the most important piece of the whole puzzle.
Voldemort and Harry are circling each other, and it strikes Regulus how much of a difference it is to earlier scenes. Now, Harry seems to be all calm confidence while Voldemort’s eyes are burning with agitation. Now, Harry speaks and is listened to, and Voldemort snarls in response.
Regulus almost laughs when Harry offers the man who has tormented him his whole life a last chance at remorse. Almost laughs because it’s that or starting to cry, and he doesn’t even know why it’s this, of all things, that makes his eyes burn.
Then again, maybe he does all too well.
Voldemort casts and Regulus’ heart stutters in his chest. Voldemort casts and Harry does as well—yet again, nothing but a Disarming Spell against a Killing Curse. For the second time, the Killing Curse rebounds, Voldemort’s wand flying through the air and getting caught neatly by Harry. The slump of Voldemort’s body somehow sounds more final than it did the first time.
Cheers are breaking out all throughout the hall, but the memory fades.
They stand in silence in the empty space, neither of them looking at the other.
“Did you hear what I said, in the memory? Why Voldemort’s spells were useless?” 
“Something about both your mother’s protection and the wand’s allegiance. The Elder Wand—but it’s nothing but a myth, isn’t it?”
Harry laughs, soft and brief. “Not a myth. Remember earlier, the scenes about the story of the three brothers? How I drove Hermione up the wall with my insistence to go after the Deathly Hallows instead? The Resurrection Stone?”
Regulus does; had wondered why Harry had shown him at all when every other memory served a clear purpose. He knows the stories of course; every wizarding child does, in one variation or another. Every wizarding child also knows that it’s nothing more than that—stories.
“Do you mean to tell me—”
“I mastered them. All of them. The cloak was mine, to begin with, and Dumbledore left me the stone after he destroyed the Horcrux Tom made out of it. And through a rather complicated, highly unlikely chain of events, I also gained mastery of the Elder Wand. Even though I got rid of both the stone of the wand in the final battle, I mastered them.”
And really, it’s not that Regulus can’t see what he’s getting at, but he’s also never been one to believe in fairy tales, and so he shakes his head.
Harry smiles, and it’s somehow both indulgent and so, so tired.
“Knew you wouldn’t just buy it,” he says, shaking his head. He hesitates, grief washing across his face in a deluge unlike any other. “Alright. One last memory, then.”
Before Regulus gets a chance to answer, the white around them lifts.
Once again, it’s a fight. Screams are cutting through the air, spells illuminating the evening, and it takes Regulus a few moments to recognize Diagon Alley and find Harry in the midst of it.
He’s older, about as old as Sirius and James and Lily were in the very first memory, although it’s hard to tell through the chaos raging on around them.
“It didn’t all go back to normal once Voldemort was defeated,” Harry says, his eyes fixed on a specific point of the fight. “For a while, it did, everyone too relieved that it was over. Or, in the case of the remaining Death Eaters, too afraid of getting caught. But the society that allowed Voldemort to rise in the first place didn’t change, and so it was only a matter of time.”
“Another Dark Lord?” Regulus asks, and the words taste like horror on his tongue.
“Rather smaller cells of extremists, trying to gain traction through violence. Of course, people kept fighting back, others simply couldn’t bring themselves to care anymore, and overall, it had even less success than—”
An earth-shattering boom cuts him off. The memory itself shakes, and Harry’s nails bury painfully into Regulus’ hand. When he tears his eyes away from the wreckage around them, Harry is white as a sheet, his whole face scrunched up as if he’s in pain.
“Are you—” Regulus starts, but Harry shakes his head sharply, air rattling audibly through his lungs.
Regulus stares around them, at the remains of storefronts and the rubble littering the street. At the motionless bodies everywhere. He tries finding Harry among them, searches for the black mop of hair, but he isn’t successful before the memory trembles and changes once more.
Slowly, Harry loosens his grip on Regulus’ hand, even as he still seems more shaken than Regulus has seen him through this whole ordeal.
He wants to ask, wants to reassure himself and Harry both, but he doesn’t think asking if Harry died this time would be helpful. Doesn’t think that are you alright would cut it, and so he stays silent. Looks around, and still finds himself surprised when once again the vast, white space appears around them, slowly melting into Kings Cross.
It’s not Dumbledore who appears this time. It’s a woman, and on second glance, Regulus recognizes her, just as the Harry from the memory whispers, “Mum?”
“Harry.”
“Is that really you?”
There’s so much tentative hope in Harry’s voice, it’s physically painful to hear.
The woman smiles with a sigh as she crouches down next to Harry. “I am whatever you wish to see.”
“I—what? That doesn’t make sense, I—I died.”
A tinkling laugh slips past her lips, reverberating through the empty space. “You’ve been here before. What do you think?”
Harry flinches back. “You’re not her,” he spits, and he sounds like the eleven-year-old boy again, snarling into Voldemort’s face.
“I’m not. I cannot be anything, and I am everything at once. I am what you would call death, and yet I am merely a concept if you will. A god, perhaps, but then, gods do not have masters now, do they?”
Silence reigns for long moments, Harry’s hands clenching and unclenching in his lap. Eventually, his face hardens, and now there’s every fight, every loss and every moment of grief carving into his expression. Now he does not look like an eleven-year-old boy at all, but someone twice, thrice his age.
“Why am I here? My mother’s protection has long run out.”
“Indeed it has. Tell me, Harry, do you think your mother was the first to sacrifice herself for her child?”
If Regulus were honest, he had asked himself the same question. Had wondered if Lily Evans might have been shrewder than people gave her credit for because magic does not work like this, not even when Voldemort offered her a choice.
“Just answer me,” Harry presses out, his voice trembling, and Regulus can feel the same fury radiating off of Harry beside him.
“Very well. You’ve mastered the Hallows, Harry Potter. I assume you know the stories—it grants you the powers of the Master of Death. The power to return to life, how often and wherever you wish to.”
“It’s nothing but a story.”
“As the Elder Wand turned out to be nothing but a story? The Resurrection Stone?”
Harry turns his face away, a muscle in his jaw jumping, and the space goes silent once more.
“Ron and Hermione, are they—did they… Are they alive?”
“No, they’re not. No one survived today’s attack.”
“No one but me.”
“Currently, you are not alive either.”
Harry huffs, pushing himself to his feet and walking a few steps away. He whirls back around though, fisting a hand into his hair. “Last time, I had a choice. A choice to move on or go back.”
The woman—the being—follows him gracefully, head tilted. “You had, and you do. This is no curse of eternal life. But you also have a choice of where you want to return to. The moment you died. The past. The future. You can go back and return here as many times as you’d like before deciding to move on. Once you have moved on though…” It makes a sweeping gesture and gives a little shrug, the implied meaning all too clear.
Regulus’ head is spinning, and his knees are close to buckling.
Harry’s silent and tense, both next to him and where he stands in the wide, open expanse of nothingness. Distantly, Regulus thinks that he should look small. Lost.
He doesn’t. Overwhelmed, yes. Angry, definitely. Very much like he’s considering his chances at cursing the being wearing the face of his mother and the whole open space around him.
“You do not have an eternity to answer, however.”
Harry’s eyes narrow and he growls, his jaw working. “Fine,” he spits. “Fine. I want to go back—to my parents’ time if you please.”
If he had hoped that the contempt in his tone would rattle the being, he is sorely disappointed. Instead, he gets a brilliant smile that makes him flinch, and everything shifts and fades again.
When Regulus blinks the spots out of his vision, he’s looking at the same small boy who needled him into turning his brother’s tie green, standing in front of a manor with a bag in his hands. He’s slightly green around the nose, and it takes him long moments to smooth the anger off his face.
To close his eyes, draw a deep breath, and approach the door to ring the bell.
Coming out of the Pensive is disorientating, to put it mildly.
Regulus staggers as soon as they emerge and only Harry’s quick reflexes keep him from stumbling over his feet. He doesn’t protest when Harry moves them towards the couch, and Regulus drops into the cushions only to instantly close his eyes, willing his head to stop spinning.
The fire in the hearth has burned down to a glimmer, and he hears Harry murmuring a spell to reignite it. Hears the plop of two bottles being opened, and he only hums in acknowledgement when Harry presses one of them into his hands.
To his credit, Harry stays silent. Regulus can hear him breathing, can feel the warmth coming from his body against his thigh. The longer he thinks, the more it loses its comfort, until he shifts to put more space between them.
“So,” Regulus finally says, his voice hoarse. “You’ve actually lived a life up into your twenties already.”
It should sound ludicrous. Should be followed by a laugh as is every ridiculous, impossible joke that didn’t have much effort put into it. Unfortunately, it only tastes ashen, bringing a weight with it that Regulus isn’t sure he’ll ever be able to shake again.
“I—I’m not sure what to say to that, to be honest,” Harry says, exhaustion ringing through his voice. Regulus knows that if he were to look at him, he’d find a universe of grief on Harry’s face.
He doesn’t look. Clenches his jaw and tries to align all the memories into something that makes sense.
“You said you’d prove to me that joining Voldemort was a bad decision. Don’t get me wrong, it definitely proved that, but it’s not like I didn’t already know. What you haven’t done is show me what happened to me.”
Finally, he turns and meets Harry’s eyes. He knows impatience and anger must be clear on his face because it’s all he can do to not snarl at Harry how he could lie for so, so long.
It’s not a particularly fair accusation, of course. It’s not something you just tell people, and yet. And yet, he remembers all the times he confided in Harry. All the times he laid himself bare, all the times he thought the trust between them went both ways.
All the times that guilt was gnawing away at him for how they drifted apart. Meanwhile, Harry had been holding his secrets so close to his chest.
Harry doesn’t answer, avoiding meeting Regulus’ eyes and his fingers white-knuckled around his bottle.
“Harry,” he says, low. “What happened to me, in this whole story of yours?”
It’s less a question and more a demand, and Harry winces. Exhales in a rush and closes his eyes before meeting Regulus’.
“It was intentional, that I didn’t show you. It’s—it’s not—”
“I want to know.”
I deserve to know, he wants to say, but he doesn’t know if that’s true. If he deserves anything on a life that’s his but also isn’t, to demand more from Harry even if he wants for so many things.
He isn’t sure of anything right now, and his skin feels too tight with it, his chest too small to contain his racing heart.
Harry sighs, bowing his head. “Alright,” he says, and the defeat in his voice cuts through Regulus’ anger enough that he keeps his mouth shut, at least.
“You were sorted into Slytherin as well, and you fell out with Sirius eventually. I don’t know when, exactly, it happened because he never told me, but as far as I understood it, it was long before he left.”
That, at least, isn’t any less than Regulus had expected. Still, his ribs seem to carve inward at the idea of missing those few happy years that he was granted.
“Again, I don’t know this for certain, but according to him, you never moved away from your parents’ beliefs. There were newspaper articles on Voldemort in your bedroom and Kreacher never said anything to the opposite. You joined just before turning seventeen as well, and it’s feasible to believe that your parents had their hands in it, but there’s little to suggest that you didn’t want to.”
“Little?” Regulus interrupts, his mind latching onto the single word with a desperation that would’ve brought him to his knees if he wasn’t already sitting down.
Harry’s lips twitch faintly, and he meets Regulus’ eyes for a fraction of a second before fixing his gaze back on the fire. “Sometime after you finished school and really joined the ranks, he asked for a house-elf, and you offered Kreacher. You ordered him to come back afterwards, probably on instinct, but who’s to say.”
The way none of what Harry is telling him holds any certainty—the way so much about his life seems to have been lost leaves him cold, air stumbling through his lungs. It shouldn’t matter, in the grand scheme of things; it’s not his life, not really. It’s not as if the Harry they’ve seen had many links to Regulus beyond a few, depressing years with Sirius and the childhood home Regulus grew up in.
Except that it does; except for how those links should’ve afforded more insight than whatever Kreacher and the decorations of his bedroom had to offer.
“Kreacher was on the brink of death when he returned to you, and Voldemort very much intended for him to die too. He was never meant to come back because what Voldemort used him for was testing the defences on the cave where he hid the locket Horcrux.” 
Merlin, but Regulus almost doesn’t want to hear what Harry has to say next. Doesn’t want to know if there had been a version of himself that cared so little about anyone else that he wasn’t bothered by the suffering of the elf that practically raised him.
“You didn’t take it well,” Harry says, and the fondness in his voice joins the sudden rush of relief, chasing some of the numbness out of Regulus’ veins.
It doesn’t last longs, Harry’s face shuttering once more, and he doesn’t go on. Stares into the fire, the lines of his profile tense as his jaw works.
Regulus wants to push, but he doesn’t. Has known Harry for long enough to know when to prod and when to wait things out, and as much as a part of him doesn’t want to know, it’s a drop of reluctance in an ocean of need. For a sign that not all of him would have been rotten if not for the boy sitting next to him, that there had been something, anything good within him to begin with.
“You nursed him back to health, and between what he was able to tell you and your own research, you somehow figured out that Voldemort created a Horcrux. Long before Dumbledore ever did—you’ve always been scarily smart,” Harry says, his eyes warm as they flicker towards Regulus.
“From there on it’s a lot of guesswork again, and also why I said little, earlier. As much as it was obvious from what Kreacher told me that you were fond of each other, I don’t know if what Voldemort did to him would’ve been enough to change your mind if you had been absolutely convinced of the cause.”
It’s a good point; he doubts that Bellatrix or even Barty, spiralling as he already is, would care much for the life of anyone—much less a house-elf—as long as it got them appreciation from their lord.
Then again, it would be easier to judge if Harry got to the point. His impatience must be notable too because Harry draws another deep breath, his face darkening.
“You must’ve felt like there was no one left to turn to, and so you intended to steal the Horcrux on your own. Only Kreacher knew, and I don’t think you ever expected to survive because not only did you steal the locket, but you also left a replacement with a note inside.”
“What did it say?”
He’s not sure why he asks. Isn’t sure why it feels important when the implications are so very glaring—that he died, alone, in a cave full of nightmares and Inferi only shortly after leaving school.
Harry’s smiling again though, faint but amusement so unmistakeably clear. “To the Dark Lord. I know I will be dead long before you read this, but I want you to know that it was I who discovered your secret. I have stolen the real Horcrux and intend to destroy it as soon as I can. I face death in the hope that when you meet your match you will be mortal once more. R.A.B.”
Regulus can’t help it; he laughs. He laughs until his body is shaking with it and tears are prickling in his eyes, and it has a definite undercurrent of hysteria. Harry merely presses their knees together and waits until he’s calmed down again.
“Did he ever find it?” 
Harry sobers, his eyes flicking away. “No, he didn’t. Dumbledore and I were the ones who found it.”
“So not only did I die for nothing, but I also made it harder for you.” He sounds sardonic, bitter, and it shouldn’t matter because it’s not his life, it hasn’t—technically—even happened yet, but there’s still acid burning at the back of his throat.
There’s still the same, tight feeling in his chest that had been there when they watched the memory of Harry and Dumbledore in the cave, and it shouldn’t make sense, but it does.
“I’m sorry,” Harry says, reaching out to find Regulus’ hand, but he flinches away. Doesn’t think he could bear the contact right now, his whole body overwhelmed with grief and anger and helplessness.
Harry sighs again, his head tipping back. “You still did the right thing, though. You realised on your own that you didn’t want to be a part of it any longer. You didn’t need anyone to tell you, just—someone to tell you sooner, maybe. To make sure that you would never end up in that blasted cave in the first place, with no other way to go but down.”
And that’s—that’s what tips everything into solid, scathing fury, charring his bones and making his blood boil. He clenches his hands until he’s sure the imprint of his nails won’t leave his skin for days. When that isn’t enough, he jumps up, putting more space between them.
“I knew you were taking all this too well,” Harry mutters behind him, and Regulus whirls around, barely keeping himself from reaching for his wand.
“So, that’s what all this was about?” he spits, gesturing between them. “Coming back, befriending me, making sure I’d change my mind—all so that you could live out your bloody saviour complex once more?”
His words are aiming to harm now, to cut. To channel the way his heart seems to be tearing apart somewhere outside of his own body, and he doesn’t care. Doesn’t care for how Harry’s face falls, for how something dark shines in the black of his eyes.
All Regulus can think, all that’s reverberating through his skull is a cacophony of none of this was real, and he must think me such an idiot, and how, how in Merlin’s name could I ever be stupid enough to fall for someone who sees me as nothing more than the small, helpless baby-Death Eater who can be saved?
The doubts are already winding around his neck, whispering into his ear that it might not even have been for his sake. Not for his sake but for Sirius’, the scenes between them from the memories and how Harry had stuck to Sirius’ side through the last year all pushing to the forefront of his mind.
“No, of course not,” Harry finally says, taking a step towards Regulus.
He steps back.
“I never even planned to—”
“Do not lie to me,” he snarls, his voice going high, and he’s not going to cry, he’s not. Not here, not like this, not even when Harry has seen him cry before. Not with how the mere idea only adds to the whole feeling of failure.
“I’m not—”
“You’ve lied to me for all these years,” he says, low and vicious. “Since the very first day that I’ve met you. Tell me, how am I supposed to believe a single word that comes out of your mouth?”
Harry stills and Regulus doesn’t know how it’s possible but somehow his face both falls and goes hard.

And really, that would figure, wouldn’t it? That his parents wouldn’t consider the possibility that Regulus doesn’t want the life they envisioned for him, enslaved to a megalomaniac who’s insane enough to tear his soul into seven different pieces.
He’s not sure if he should be proud of the deception or insulted at the lack of credit. He decides to go with the former because truly, somewhere between the last summer and getting spat out of the Pensive, he has lost all regards for what his parents think of him.
“So it’s more of a misplaced mission to rescue my poor, kidnapped self than a hunt for my head.”
Harry shifts until he sits next to him, pressing their shoulders together.
Sometimes, Regulus thinks it should scare him how well Harry can read him.
“Something like that,” Sirius says, his head tilting to the side as his fingers drum a restless rhythm against the armrest of the chair he’s sharing with James. “But to be perfectly honest, a lot of her complaints are about how it will make them look in front of the Dark Lord if you don’t turn up to your initiation, so I’d be reluctant to call it actual concern.”
“Sirius,” James hisses, eyes narrowed into slits, but Regulus waves him off.
“If there’s one thing I’m not surprised about, it’s that,” he says. Maybe it should be more harrowing, but he’s seen how easy it was for their parents to give up on Sirius, and he has long since lost any delusions about their care for him.
“It doesn’t really make a difference anyway, does it?” Harry asks mildly, and at James’ glare, raises his hands in a gesture of placation. “Not that they don’t care even though it’s barely a surprise. But if they’re looking for him because they believe he didn’t disappear on his own volition or not—they’re looking for him either way and Vol—the Dark Lord will care even less.”
“Why aren’t you saying his name?” Regulus asks, aware that it barely matters right now but thrown by the sudden change.
Harry grimaces, his eyes flicking to Sirius and James before settling on him. “He put a curse on his name recently, as far as I’m aware. It basically bypasses any wards and summons Death Eaters to wherever you are.”
“Good to know,” he bites out, sending Harry a glare that he’s sure isn’t missed by either Sirius or James.
“Anyway,” Harry says after rolling his eyes at him, “Bottom line is, we have to keep being careful and returning to Hogwarts isn’t an option. When was your initiation supposed to take place again?”
“In three days.”
Just a little more than a week before he turns seventeen, and this—this still has bitterness and contempt rushing through his veins regardless of how he slipped away at the last possible second.
“Bastards,” Sirius mutters, clearly understanding the implications, and yet it soothes some of Regulus’ own anger.
“Well. Nothing but to wait and see how Mister Voldy-pants is going to take it,” Harry says, his grin sharp and effectively breaking the tension.
James bursts out laughing first, Sirius not far behind, and soon they’re all clutching their stomachs, eyes wet with laughter and maybe, a little bit of hysteria.
Harry’s leg is still warm and solid against Regulus’ though, and he’s so, so doomed.
The night before he turns seventeen—and even without the Damocles sword hovering above his neck, it still feels like it will finally allow him to breathe again—he’s holed up in his bed, a book on Ancient Egypt propped up on his legs.
One of the many upsides of living with the Potters is that their library is actually equipped with all manners of books. It has never been as painfully obvious how very lacking the library at Grimmauld Place is as the moment he set foot in there for the first time.
Fleamont had been so excited about finally having someone to share the love he so clearly has for his collection with, they’d got lost in the endless rows of books until Euphemia had to practically drag them out of there.
A Tempus is glowing softly beside him, and he smiles to himself at the two hours he has left until it will strike midnight.
Of course, he should’ve expected Harry to have his own ideas about the whole thing.
The door creaks open, and he just about spotted the mop of black hair before Harry lands on his legs, bouncing slightly. He’s wearing a washed-out jumper that’s too big on him, his eyes bright in the dim light, and for a moment, Regulus can’t breathe.
“You didn’t think I’d let you read into your coming of age, did you?” Harry asks, grin firmly in place. It’s only then that Regulus notices how Harry’s hands are hidden behind his back.
He raises a questioning brow, trying his very best to appear unimpressed because it’s never a good idea to enable Harry too much. He’s rather sure that hasn’t changed.
Harry’s grin turns impossibly wider, and he reveals two bottles of Firewhiskey with a flourish and a mock bow. Regulus is helpless against the snort, and he sits up straighter.
“Where in Merlin’s name did you get those from?”
“I asked James to bring them. It was more effort to keep Sirius and him from joining us than convincing him to be honest.”
“Of course it was.”
“We don’t have to,” Harry says, his head tilting. For all their years living in each other’s pockets, Regulus has never figured out if disappointment is the one emotion that Harry is incredibly good at hiding, or if there truly are only a handful of times where Regulus did let him down.
“Don’t be silly, of course, I do,” he says, meaning it more than he probably should. “Are you sure Fleamont and Euphemia won’t mind?”
Harry shrugs, his eyes warm on Regulus, and suddenly he’s more than glad for the dim light. “Actually, the second bottle is from Fleamont, so I’d wager a guess and say no.”
Regulus laughs, the last threads of apprehension slipping away. He marks his page in the book and puts it on the nightstand before raising a brow at Harry. “Did you have any further plans or are we going to get drunk in our room like boys at a boarding school?”
“I knew I should’ve never let you read all those mediocre Muggle novels,” Harry says with a sigh, unfolding himself from the bed. “But yes, I do actually have a plan. Come on.”
Knowing that asking would most likely get him nowhere, Regulus follows suit, grabbing a jumper before following Harry out of the room.
The house is dark and silent, only the light of Harry’s wand illuminating the corridors they’re walking through, and Regulus soon loses track of where they’re going except for clearly upstairs.
Eventually, they reach the end of a corridor, and Harry presses the bottles into Regulus’ hands without further comment. He takes them, watching curiously as Harry taps his wand against a seemingly unremarkable stretch of wall.
A low grinding sound, and a staircase materializes in front of them, opening into what has to be the attic.
“Are you—”
“Shh, just trust me.”
Regulus bites down on a myriad of things he could but definitely shouldn’t say to that, following silently.
It does turn out to be an attic, one stuffed with discarded furniture and boxes, but Harry doesn’t stop. It probably says something that it takes Regulus a moment to remember that in normal homes, stuffed attics do not mean that you have to be careful not to touch anything if you don’t want to get cursed.
They slowly navigate their way along a narrow path until they reach the other end and Harry fiddles with what appears to be a window until it gives with a screech.
Harry doesn’t seem bothered by the noise, lifting himself out of it into the darkness behind. His face appears only seconds later, the light of his wand casting shadows across his face. “Give me the bottles and come on.”
Excitement is sprawling through Regulus’ chest, and he doesn’t hesitate before he does as told. Once he’s heaved himself through the narrow window, he finds himself on a roof terrace.
It’s small, barely big enough to fit three people, but there are a blanket and pillows spread out on the ground, and several glasses with bluebell flames scattered around.
Harry has planned this, beyond asking James to get them a bottle of Firewhiskey, and the sudden lump in his throat renders him unable to speak even if he wanted to. He plops down on the blankets, staring out over the dark grounds of Potter Manor and the night sky stretching far above them.
Harry sits down beside him, leaning back against one of the walls enclosing the space on three sides, and cracks open one of the bottles. He stares at it, his brows knitting together before he grins at Regulus.
“Well, we might have blankets and light, but I forgot glasses. Out of the bottle, it is.”
Regulus laughs, the tension breaking, and he takes the offered whiskey to take the first sip. It burns down his throat, leaving warmth pooling in his stomach, and he closes his eyes.
Beside him, Harry mutters a low warming charm, and the biting January cold recedes slightly. It’s still there, fresh against Regulus’ skin, but no longer trying to make a home underneath his clothes.
“Thank you.” As much as he means this, right here, and how he didn’t even know how much he needed it, there are also a hundred other things he wants to thank him for.
Harry merely hums, knocking their ankles together, and Regulus knows it’s alright. That somehow, Harry understands, always had, and that he doesn’t have to say anything else if he doesn’t want to.
“Any wishes for turning seventeen?” Harry eventually breaks the silence, and Regulus turns to look at him.
The bottle is standing between them, already half-emptied, and he can feel the effects of the alcohol. His limbs are loose and his head the slightest bit fuzzy around the edges, though by no means close to drunk yet.
“Not really—nothing specific, at least? What did you wish for when you turned seventeen? The first time at least?”
It should be more awkward, to ask about it like that, but here on a secluded corner of a rooftop with the winter sky above them, it feels less absurd than in the light of day.
“To survive the war. For my friends to survive the war. The bar was pretty low, to be honest,” Harry says, his voice quiet. “Well, and I was pretty happy about being able to do magic even if it was only to summon my glasses.”
Regulus’ lips twitch, at the same time as his chest tightens. “It’s not all that different. I mean, for all that I’ve avoided the worst of it, it’s not over yet. Sirius and James are out there, Remus too, and we can’t hide out here forever.”
“We could,” Harry says, and he sounds like he means it. Sounds as if Regulus only has to say the word, and Harry would stay with him even as Regulus can tell that he’s itching to be out there too, no matter how well he hides it.
It’s something he has avoided thinking about, ever since they’ve left Hogwarts. There was ever only one conclusion to arrive at though, as inevitable as it had been that his whole life would change, once Harry set foot in it.
“Maybe,” he says, taking another sip before handing the bottle to Harry. “But it would be rather boring, don’t you think?”
Harry’s laugh cuts through the night air, and it’s not all that difficult to accept that he’d go to war for it.
“So, what’s your plan then?”
“Well, you’re the one with the intel on how to kill a Dark Lord, aren’t you?”
“Fair enough,” Harry says with a hum, sobering slightly. “It’s far less fun than it sounds. Even if this time around, I do know what I’m searching for and where to search, it doesn’t mean it’ll be easy—”
“Yes, that cave rather clued me into that, thanks.”
“Merlin but sometimes you’re infuriating,” Harry huffs, shaking his head. He hands the bottle back though, their fingers brushing together, and Regulus has to truly focus to not let it distract him. “I destroyed the diary in my second year, but who knows where it is now. Who knows if the cup is already in Bellatrix’s vault, and even if it is, I’m not sure if my luck can bear breaking into Gringotts twice.”
“Alright, yes, I get your point. How about we keep the actual planning to a time where we’re at least both sober?” Regulus asks, and for all the fear that’s tingling up and down his spine, there’s also amusement buzzing in his chest at the focused frown between Harry’s brows.
It smooths out at his words, and Harry smiles at him, so very soft. “That’s why you’re the brain in this whole thing.”
“Merlin help us.”
“That he should anyway.”
Regulus pushes him because really, what else can he do?
They lapse into silence again, and he lets his mind wander. It doesn’t stray far, Harry such a fixed point in both his past and future, and words tumble out of his mouth before he has given them any permission to do so. “I’m sorry.”
Harry seems to startle, sitting up straighter. He leans forward, arms propped on his knees, and there’s honest confusion shining in his eyes. It only makes Regulus feel worse.
“What for?”
Regulus laughs, but it’s lacking any humour. “Sometimes I wonder if you truly are this selfless. You just—Merlin, Harry. For all the shit I’ve pulled over the last two years. For pushing you away when all you ever tried to do was being there for me. For blowing up in your face when you showed me all the things you—”
“Stop,” Harry says, low and forceful. His fingers curl around Regulus’ wrist, and he tugs until Regulus meets his eyes. “You had a right to be upset, even if I had a right to not tell you about it sooner. None of this was ever easy, and it’s not your fault or my fault, but that doesn’t mean we’re not allowed to take time to come to terms with it.”
“When have you become so wise?” he chokes out, aiming for light-hearted but missing by a mile.
“I’m not, but Hermione was, and she made sure to remind me so often that it’s impossible to forget,” Harry deadpans, and Regulus’ lips curl up despite himself.
“Still,” he says, forcing himself to sober. Forcing himself to wrap his fingers around Harry’s wrist in return and not give away how very much the gesture means to him. “If we’re allowed to need time to come to terms with it, we’re also allowed to apologize, right? And I truly am sorry.”
Harry huffs a laugh, his fingers pressing against Regulus’ pulse point. “You and Hermione would’ve got along so well,” he says, wistful. “If that’s what you need to hear, it’s alright. It wasn’t particularly great, but I understood why it took you some time.”
Regulus doesn’t have an answer to that, and he takes the whiskey out of Harry’s hand if only to distract himself. Their other hands stay entwined though, and Regulus doesn’t feel like letting go. Doesn’t feel like pulling away again, and maybe it’s only the alcohol slowly setting in, but there seems to be a world of possibilities stretching between them, replacing the weight of the last two years.
Harry moves until he’s stretched out beside Regulus, not once letting go of his hand. It’s slightly uncomfortable, and so he mirrors Harry’s position, their shoulders pressing together with their hands between them.
“Is it weird, sometimes? To technically be older than all of us? To go to school with your own parents?”
He’s rather certain that he would’ve never asked if his mind wasn’t swimming comfortably, all the reasons for why it’s a bad idea slipping away before he can take a hold of them.
It’s something that he’s been wondering about for the last few weeks. Maybe it wouldn’t matter so much if all Regulus felt was friendship. If there wasn’t a flicker of hope, unrelenting, burning in his chest, that had only been growing in strength ever since he had decided to never return to Grimmauld Place.
“A bit? Not really? It’s—it also doesn't feel like I am? I have the memories, but I still feel like I'm sixteen years old, not like I've already lived a life. It's more present when I watch the memories but otherwise, it's... distant. Unreal. It’s hard to explain, to be honest. That being said, it was definitely weird to interact with my parents in the beginning or to share a house with people who actively tried to kill me before.”
Regulus isn’t quite sure what to make of it. Isn’t quite sure what he wanted to hear in the first place but that this is probably as good as he’s going to get. “You did mention it though when you found out about the plans for my initiation.”
Harry hums, rolling onto his side and emptying the remains of the bottle. He feels around for the second one until he finds it, cracking it open and handing it to Regulus before he goes on. “As I said, rationally, the memories are there. Rationally, I know that some ways of how I saw the world at sixteen were different from how I viewed it at twenty-three. It doesn’t necessarily affect everything else, but it’s not like I don’t know either.”
“Doesn’t it mess with your head sometimes?”
Harry laughs, his head tipping back. “Sometimes, yes. But ultimately, the only thing I can do is to not overthink it and let my gut make the decisions. It never failed me, and if I start second-guessing myself at every turn, I’ll just go mad.”
It makes sense, in a weird kind of way, even if there’s still uncertainty tickling at the base of Regulus’ skull. He’s not sure how to voice it though, how to pin the feeling down at all, and so he squeezes Harry’s hand. Focuses on the warmth of his fingers, now solid between his, and reminds himself that if there’s one thing he knows—if there’s one thing that he’s absolutely sure about—it’s that it is impossible to make Harry do anything he doesn’t want to do.
That Harry wouldn’t be here if he didn’t want to be, and maybe—maybe that’s enough.
“I’m glad you turned up,” he says, turning his head to look at Harry. He startles at how close they are, at how he can make out the faint array of freckles across Harry’s nose in the flickering light from the bluebell flames, the pale white lines spreading off from his scar.
“Yeah?” Harry asks, his voice low. His eyes are wide, roaming over Regulus’ face, and the air seems to shift, tension curling between them.
Regulus’ heart is thundering against his ribs, his throat dry, and he swallows against how his heart is trying to lodge itself right there. “Yeah, I don’t—you’re the best thing that could’ve happened to me, and for all that you’ve pulled me into a whole lot of nonsense, I’d start a hundred prank wars with Sirius if it brought me here.”
Harry’s fingers tighten around his and his eyes flutter. Regulus can see him swallow, his eyes tracing the movement of Harry’s throat, and it doesn’t matter that his head is buzzing. Doesn’t matter that he’s still not sure if he truly deserves any of this or if Harry will one day realise that Regulus is truly not worth all the trouble.
He’s not sure where the courage comes from either, but he turns, leaving only a hairbreadth of space between them. Lets his fingers finally, finally slip into Harry’s hair, and it’s exactly as soft as he expected it to be.
“Are you—” Harry starts, and his voice is hoarse, his eyes dark when he blinks slowly.
“Yeah,” Regulus says, and he sounds just as choked, his hands trembling.
Harry watches him for a few beats longer, his eyes flickering from Regulus’ eyes to his lips, and then he leans forward. Brushes their lips together, lingering there briefly before leaning their foreheads together.
Regulus’ whole body is abuzz with it, his lips tingling, and he allows Harry to hover there until he can’t bear it any longer. He presses closer, his hand carving around Harry’s neck, and the next kiss is firmer, more insistent.
He has never believed in fireworks going off at kissing someone, not even after all this time he had longed to find out if kissing Harry would truly feel as great as he made it out to be, but it does come pretty damn close.
Harry’s hand finds his waist, fingers tightening, and his teeth graze against Regulus’ bottom lip before he draws away again. It’s not far, his breath still fanning over Regulus’ lips, and he has to keep his eyes closed. Has to keep his eyes closed and let the sensations wash over him because he doesn’t think he could look at Harry and not let it all show on his face.
“You were never supposed to draw me in like this,” Harry whispers, and Regulus isn’t sure if he’s supposed to hear it at all. “You completely crept up on me and I can’t even bring myself to regret a single moment of it. I was never supposed to let anyone close, much less this close, and yet here you are, making me spill all my secrets to you and making me stay.”
The admission feels monumental, bigger than he has any hope of comprehending, of ever finding an adequate answer for. There’s nothing he can do but kiss Harry again, to tighten his grip on Harry’s hair and press closer until there isn’t any space left between them.
Harry tastes of whiskey and night air, his nose cold against Regulus’ face, and it’s all a bit messy and drunk but it’s also easily the best thing Regulus has ever experienced.
It’s not like fireworks, but it is a lot like flying. Like the moment when his fingers finally curl around the snitch, fluttering against his palm, while he’s sure he’s able to hear Harry cheer in the stands. It’s a lot like that, but better; like knowing that it will last beyond the first high of a won game.
He doesn’t think he’d be able to let this go again, not for anything in the world.
The next morning arrives with harsh light and a pounding headache, and it takes Regulus long, disorientated moments until he realises that he’s not alone in his bed.
The second realisation is that he’s still dressed in yesterday’s clothes, and only then does he recognise the shape of the fingers still linked with his. All at once, the last night comes rushing back in a disorientating array of colours and sensations.
Harry grumbles lowly, shifting, and Regulus isn’t sure if he wants him to wake up. Isn’t sure if he doesn’t want to get up and flee because the longer he’s thinking, the deeper is terror carving itself into his chest at what the light of day could possibly bring with it.
There has been little doubt last night about what this meant to him, to both of them. In retrospect, he isn’t all that sure anymore if his whiskey-soaked brain didn’t apply far more meaning to what Harry was saying than had been there.
He carefully tries to disentangle himself from the heap of limbs they’ve become—and he doesn’t think about how this might be the last time they’re this close, he doesn’t—and move out of the bed. Tries to tell himself that maybe Harry doesn’t remember, that maybe he can pretend that nothing happened and avoid all the inevitable repercussions.
Of course, he should’ve learned by now that Harry never makes life easy on him. His grip on Regulus tightens and he grumbles again before lifting his head, eyes unfocused before settling on Regulus.
They stay frozen like that for a few long seconds that feel like minutes, and then Harry seems to wake up all at once.
“Are you alright?” he asks, propping himself up. His brows knit together in obvious concern, and Regulus wants to weep at the familiar expression.
“Sure,” he says, marvelling at how smooth his voice comes out, at how his shrug barely feels awkward.
“You’re not,” Harry states, sitting up fully. He doesn’t let go of Regulus’ hand, but his grip is loose enough that Regulus could pull away if he wanted to.
He doesn’t know what he wants, and his head is spinning, his gut churning.
“Just—I—you don’t have to act like it meant something,” he says, and it truly says something about the hangover he has that the words make it past his lips at all.
Hurt flashes across Harry’s face, lightning-fast. It’s gone as soon as it appeared. “What are you talking about?”
Regulus laughs, short and bitter, and pulls his hand away after all. He doesn’t think he’ll be able to have this conversation any other way. “What happened last night, you—I’m me, and you’re you, and just because I managed to take a right turn before the inevitable fall, doesn’t mean that has changed.”
He gets up, needing to move, needing to put space between them. Harry follows even though he leaves distance between them, and Regulus doesn’t know if he should be grateful or see it as just another confirmation of what he’s dreading to be the truth.
“You’re not making sense,” Harry says, and his voice is tense in a way that belies how very much this affects him. “Are you—do you regret it? Because if you do, obviously, that’s fine. I’m not—we don’t have to be together if that’s not what you want, but you can just tell me. You don’t have to make up—”
“I’m not making anything up!” he snaps, his nails burying into his palms. A part of his mind is telling him to shut up, to sit down and talk about this calmly or not talk about this at all, but it sounds too much like his father to pay any attention to it.
“You—you’re all the things that are good in this world, you’ve made all the right choices and then you somehow managed to find me and save me. For all that I love you, I’m perfectly aware that while we’re friends, I’m not anywhere close to what you deserve from this life or—or any life for that matter. Can’t you see how you deserve so much better? How there’s a hundred people who don’t come from a rotten family, who didn’t convince themselves to join a bloody Dark Lord and pushed away the one damn person who truly cared about them, and then had to be bloody saved when they realised how fucking stupid they’d been?”
His hands are shaking, and he can’t believe he said all of this. Can’t believe that Harry’s still here. Granted, staring at him like he has lost his mind, but still here, rubbing a hand over his face and drawing a deep breath.
“Merlin and Morgana, but you couldn’t have waited with this until after breakfast?” Harry mutters, his head bowed. Regulus can still see him taking a deep breath, and he tries to steel himself for whatever is going to follow his outburst.
In his experience, nothing good ever does and it costs him his last amounts of willpower to not simply flee the room and ignore the whole thing until it goes away by itself.
He’s so caught up in his spinning mind, he doesn’t notice that Harry has moved until he stands right in front of him, his hands curling around Regulus’ wrists.
“Listen to me, you absolute idiot. I’ve not befriended you to save you; in fact, you’re the one who taught me that—that I don’t have to save someone, constantly, to be content. I like you because you’re funny and smart and you made me laugh when truly very little in this world made me remotely happy. Because you took all my strange habits and oddities and found them endearing, and listened to me rant about truly stupid things, not having half an idea what I was talking about and stuck around anyway. Because you’re brave and stubborn—Merlin help me, you’re so stubborn—and even if you don’t always know how, you very much want to do the right thing.”
Harry swallows, his eyes closing briefly before he goes on. “When I came to this bloody timeline, I thought I’d watch my parents for a bit because it’s something I had never got to do, and when I died the next time, I’d move on. But you—you made me want to stay, you still make me want to stay, and I’m bloody happy, alright? Whatever else is going to happen, I’m not going to stand here and listen to you diminish that because I’m a very complicated person to make happy and if I didn’t love you so bloody much, I’d curse you six ways to Sunday for ever implying that I don’t mean it when I say that.”
Harry’s breathing is choked when he’s done, but Regulus is too caught up by the tears in Harry’s eyes, the way his hands are trembling where they’re still holding on to Regulus’ wrists.
“I—”
“Don’t you dare say anything, or I swear to Merlin—” Harry says, and then he’s pushing close, his lips pressing against Regulus’.
He can do nothing but cling to him, sinking his teeth into Harry’s lips and wrapping his arms around him, words still echoing through his skull.
It takes them a long time to break apart, and when they do, Harry’s lips are bitten red and his eyes dazed.
“Do you fucking believe me now?”
Regulus laughs, the sound somehow both wet and happier than he has ever heard it. “Alright, yes. Yes, you utter disaster of a human being, I do.”
“Look who’s talking,” Harry shoots back, leaning their foreheads together. His eyes close, and for long moments, they just breathe each other in.
“So,” Regulus finally says, a part of him still unable to believe that he truly gets to be this lucky. “You and me, hunting Horcruxes and taking the world by storm?”
Harry laughs, and it’s bright and delighted. He presses a kiss to the corner of Regulus’ mouth before meeting his eyes.
“Only you and me.”
Sirius and James step by later that day, bawling out a horrible rendition of some Muggle birthday song as soon as they’re across the doorstep. Regulus is still so ridiculously happy, he can’t even bring himself to mourn the health of his ears.
They settle into the living room, and his smile only grows when they deposit a small mountain of gifts in front of him.
Harry presses their legs together, smiling softly.
“Oh Merlin, finally!” Sirius exclaims, clapping his hands together, and Regulus jerks his head up to stare at him.
James is grinning too, one eyebrow raised. “So you finally got your shit together, I’m amazed.”
Catching on to what they’re talking about, Regulus rolls his eyes and focuses back on the presents. He lets Harry bicker it out with them as he slowly unwraps a myriad of books, drawing supplies, sweets, and prank articles that he’ll probably end up using on them.
“Thank you,” he finally says, warm contentment buzzing in his chest. Sirius waves him off, but he looks happy as well.
Eventually, though, Sirius turns sombre, and Regulus knows what’s coming before he opens his mouth. “It seems like our dear parents have finally caught on to the fact that you made a run for it.”
Regulus swallows, and Harry tangles their fingers together between them. It shouldn’t have such a grounding effect, but Regulus can’t bring himself to care.
“What makes you think that?”
Sirius’ answering smile is humourless and he shrugs. “Kreacher turned up at our flat, clearly checking for any signs of you. He kept asking about you too but neither was very successful. He didn’t tell us much but it’s probably in your best interest to avoid both our dear family and the Dark Lord at all costs.”
A pang resonates through his chest at the mention of Kreacher and he draws a measured breath, choosing to ignore anything beyond that. It’s not like he had planned to meet his parents or the Dark Lord for tea any time soon.
“But you two are safe?”
“I doubt they would’ve sent their elf if they could’ve come themselves, right? For now, the wards should be fine, but we’re considering to move somewhere where we can put a Fidelius on too.”
Harry goes rigid beside him. “Whatever you do, do not make Peter the secret keeper. Not even as a decoy.”
James huffs, clearly remembering all too well Harry’s animosity, but Sirius’ brows knit together. “That’s oddly specific.”
He’s right, of course, and Sirius has always been way more perceptive than people give him credit for.
Glancing at Harry, Regulus finds him smiling without any mirth. “It is. I’ll tell you someday, but not today. Until then just—trust me, please?”
It’s more of a concession than he has ever given when it comes to Peter, and both Sirius and James seem to catch on to that as well. For a moment, they all stare at each other, and Regulus can feel the nervousness radiating off of Harry.
In the end, Sirius gives a sharp nod, his eyes contemplative.

“You’re going to be alright, yeah?”
